column1: Yarmouth ( YAR-məth) is a town in Barnstable County
column3: United States
column4: Barnstable County being coextensive with Cape Cod. The population was 23
column5: 793 at the 2010 census.The town is made up of three major villages: South Yarmouth

column2: Yarmouth was inhabited by the Wampanoag
column3: an Algonquian people. In the Wôpanâak language the area was called "Mattacheese". Wampanoag tribes living in Yarmouth at the time of European settlement included the Pawkunnawkuts on both sides of the lower Bass River
column4: the Hokanums in what is now northeastern Yarmouth
column5: and the Cummaquids in what is now western Yarmouth.

column1: Yarmouth was organized and incorporated as part of the Plymouth Colony on September 3
column3: following a settlement led by John Crowe (later Crowell)
column7: the oldest town on Cape Cod. Yarmouth originally included what is now the town of Dennis
column8: which was incorporated as a separate community on June 19
column10: a town in the county of Norfolk
column11: on the east coast of England
column12: which is itself at the mouth of the River Yare. Though none of the initial settlers hailed from that English town
column13: the name was possibly chosen because across the North Sea from Yarmouth is the Netherlands
column14: where a portion of the Mayflower passengers had lived in exile. This group of pilgrims arrived back in England via the port of Yarmouth before heading to the New World.In 1642 and 1645
column15: Yarmouth furnished soldiers for the Plymouth Colony's expeditions against the Narragansett. In 1648
column18: appointed Myles Standish to adjudicate land disputes among the Yarmouth settlers. Yarmouth soldiers served the Plymouth Colony in King Philip's War: fifteen Yarmouth men participated in the Great Swamp Fight without casualties
column19: but the town did lose five men at Rehoboth. Yarmouth troops also saw service in the early years of King William's War. In the early eighteenth century
column20: some of the Yarmouth veterans of King Philip's War were granted lands to settle in Gorham

column1: Yarmouth was the site of an active group of the Sons of Liberty during the American Revolution. The town's militia mustered to provide assistance to the minutemen at the Battles of Lexington and Concord
column2: but the militia returned home upon news that the rebels had already triumphed on the field. In March 1776
column3: Yarmouth troops served as part of George Washington's forces during the Fortification of Dorchester Heights. A meeting of Yarmouth citizens declared the town's independence from Great Britain on June 20
column5: Yarmouth was subject to blockade by the Royal Navy throughout the Revolutionary War.

column1: In the early years of the Republic
column2: Yarmouth shared with the rest of New England a strong support for the Federalist Party. The economy of Yarmouth was centered on maritime industries
column3: and the townspeople were consequently opposed to the Jefferson Administration's Embargo Act of 1807 and Non-Intercourse Act of 1809.On July 8
column5: the Yarmouth town meeting voted to protest the recent Congressional declaration of war with Great Britain. Along with much of the rest of coastal New England
column6: Yarmouth was subject to blockade by the Royal Navy beginning in 1814. Although the people of Yarmouth
column8: remained intensely opposed to the War of 1812
column9: local militia forces did participate in attempts to counter the blockade.

column1: Yarmouth began as a farming community in which the people of the town raised pigs
column3: and sheep. Due to livestock pasturage
column6: and the construction of the Old Colony Railroad
column7: the old-growth forests of the Wampanoag era had disappeared from Yarmouth by the end of the nineteenth century
column8: not to be replaced with stands of incipient second-growth forest until agriculture declined in the town during the twentieth century.

column1: Although agriculture was a prominent part of Yarmouth life
column2: the town's location led its people to make much of their living from the ocean. For centuries
column3: many Yarmouth men worked as whalers. In the early nineteenth century
column4: merchantmen skippered by Yarmouth captains participated in the China Trade between New England and the Cantonese trading center of Whampoa. Captain Ebenezer Sears of Yarmouth was the first American skipper to take a merchant vessel around the Cape of Good Hope. In 1854
column5: Captain Asa Eldridge of Yarmouth skippered the clipper Red Jacket
column7: between New York and Liverpool in only 13 days
column11: setting a speed record for fastest trans-Atlantic crossing by a commercial sailing vessel that has remained unbroken ever since. In 1856
column12: Captain Eldridge skippered the ill-fated steamship SS Pacific
column13: which disappeared at sea on a voyage from Liverpool to New York. The house of another Yarmouth sea captain
column15: is now a museum and home to the Historical Society of Old Yarmouth.

column1: Developers began to refashion Yarmouth into a summer resort near the end of the nineteenth century. Hotels and summer cottage communities proliferated in the first half of the twentieth century
column2: particularly along what is now Route 28. With the emergence of the car culture in the years just after World War II
column3: these were joined first by many motels (mostly along Route 28 in West Yarmouth) and later by the denser
column4: suburban pattern of residential housing construction that characterizes Yarmouth today.The headquarters of the International Fund for Animal Welfare (IFAW)
column5: a global animal welfare and conservation charity founded in 1969
column6: is located in Yarmouth Port. In 1970
column7: the national Christmas Tree Shops retail chain was founded at a location on Route 6A in Yarmouth Port.

column1: According to the United States Census Bureau
column2: the town has a total area of 28.2 square miles (73.1 km2)
column3: of which 24.1 square miles (62.5 km2) is land and 4.1 square miles (10.5 km2)
column5: is water. Yarmouth is bordered by Cape Cod Bay to the north
column8: and Barnstable to the west. Yarmouth is approximately 75 miles (121 km) southeast of Boston.

column1: The Bass River and its tributaries make up the majority of the town's border with Dennis. There are also several smaller ponds throughout the town. The Cape Cod Bay shore is marshy
column2: with several creeks flowing into it. The town's southern shore is known for its beaches
column3: from the west jetty of the Bass River to Great Island
column4: on the east and south sides of Hyannis Harbor. The town has no state forests or wildlife management areas
column5: although there are many such natural
column6: unprotected areas in town. The town is also the site of four golf courses

column1: According to the Köppen climate classification system
column3: Massachusetts has a warm-summer
column5: humid continental climate (Dfb). Dfb climates are characterized by at least one month having an average mean temperature ≤ 32.0 °F (≤ 0.0 °C)
column6: at least four months with an average mean temperature ≥ 50.0 °F (≥ 10.0 °C)
column7: all months with an average mean temperature ≤ 71.6 °F (≤ 22.0 °C)
column8: and no significant precipitation difference between seasons. The average seasonal (Nov-Apr) snowfall total is around 30 in (76 cm). The average snowiest month is February which corresponds with the annual peak in nor'easter activity. According to the United States Department of Agriculture
column9: the plant hardiness zone is 7a with an average annual extreme minimum air temperature of 0.6 °F (-17.4 °C).

column1: According to the A. W. Kuchler U.S. Potential natural vegetation Types
column3: Massachusetts would primarily contain a Northeastern Oak/Pine (110) vegetation type with a Southern Mixed Forest (26) vegetation form.

column1: Cape Cod's three major east-west routes
column3: Massachusetts Route 6A and Massachusetts Route 28
column4: all run through the town. Unlike many towns on the Cape
column5: there are no other state routes crossing between the three roads
column6: with all crossing routes being local roads. There are two exits off Route 6 (also known as the Mid-Cape Highway) in town.

column1: Freight rail service is provided by the Massachusetts Coastal Railroad from the Barnstable town line to just west of Station Avenue south of U.S. Route 6
column2: where a trash transfer station is located. Trash is loaded onto rail cars at the transfer station and hauled to the SEMASS waste-to-energy plant in Rochester. A portion of the Hyannis branch also passes through the western part of Yarmouth. The Cape Cod Central Railroad operates seasonal tourist excursions from nearby Hyannis to Sandwich and Sagamore. The nearest inter-city (Amtrak) passenger rail stations are Boston's South Station and Providence. The nearest MBTA commuter rail stations are Kingston/Route 3 and Middleborough/Lakeville
column3: providing direct service to Boston.

column1: There are also several bike paths throughout town.
The nearest airport is the Barnstable Municipal Airport
column2: just over the town line. The nearest national and international air service is at Logan International Airport in Boston.

column1: Yarmouth is represented in the Massachusetts House of Representatives as a part of the First and Second Barnstable Districts.  The town is represented in the Massachusetts Senate as a part of the Cape and Islands Districts
column2: which includes all of Cape Cod
column3: Martha's Vineyard and Nantucket except the towns of Bourne
column5: Sandwich and a portion of Barnstable.  The town is home to the Second Barracks of Troop D of the Massachusetts State Police.On the national level
column6: Yarmouth is a part of Massachusetts's 9th congressional district
column7: and is currently represented by William R. Keating.

column1: Yarmouth is governed by the open town meeting form of government
column2: and is led by a town administrator and a board of selectmen. There is a central police station
column3: and one firehouse
column4: post office and library each in South Yarmouth

column1: Yarmouth schools make up one-half of the Dennis-Yarmouth Regional School District. Yarmouth operates two elementary schools (Station Avenue and Marguerite E. Small) which serve students from pre-kindergarten through third grade and the Mattacheese Middle School for grades 6 through 7. Grades 4-5 are served at Wixon Innovative School in Dennis. The town is the home to Dennis-Yarmouth Regional High School
column2: where both towns send their grade 8-12 students. (Unlike most high schools
column3: which are 9-12) Their team colors are green and white
column4: and their mascot is the dolphin.

column1: Students who live in Yarmouth may also attend Cape Cod Regional Technical High School in Harwich or Sturgis Charter Public School in Hyannis; both for grades 9-12. In addition
column2: they may choose to attend Saint Pius X School for grades pre-kindergarten through 8
column3: or any of the other private schools in neighboring Barnstable.
